content.description:
(described in Mark Kochte's Climb Maryland!). On the right side of Castle Rock there is a low roof. Downhill about 5 feet there is a thin crack; this head up the crack toward a large corner to the right of a 2 foot roof at ~30 feet. 

  This is a fun climb!  As always, if you can't find the right holds it's harder than the grade - and there are a lot of harder holds to choose from.
content.location: To the right and ~15 feet uphill of the Castle Rock nose; downhill from small roof protruding from the hillside.

content.description: On the G side of PG. Climb obvious right-leaning flake, then follow the left-leaning crack up onto a ledge. Here you can "escape" up and left to easier, well-protected terrain OR shuffle out right along the ledge and climb the more exposed and less protected front edge of the formation.
content.protection: "PG" rating. Took gear up to 4". Gear is great until the last ~10ft. Up top, can build a gear anchor or there are some solid trees ~15 feet back from the top of the climb.
content.location: Start on the southwest (climber's left) side of the formation, at the base or a right leaning flake.

content.description: (described in Mark Kochte's Climb Maryland!). On the right side of Castle Rock there is a low roof.  An easy start on a jug gets harder very quickly.  Go up lots of tiny holds - you get a bit of a rest on a slab underneath a 2 ft roof.  Stay right out of the corner to go up over the roof.
content.location: Heading up the right side of Castle Rock, about 15-20 ft from the nose is a low roof that ends about 2 feet above the ground downhill buries into the hillside uphill.

content.description: A small south facing tower ~40ft in height embedded in the hill behind it which leads up to the summit. The formation is shaped like a thin tetrahedron with the edge facing south; thus there is a southwest face (climber left) and southeast face (climber right). Some great, overlooked lines here, though they tend to be a bit run out. Much more secluded than Middle Earth and Boyscout, and not many hikers scramble here as compared to the westview slabs.
